Oh, sweet! As a (former) songbird researcher and Nerdfighter, I’m super stoked to see the finches get mentioned on this channel. I’d be happy to go into all kinds of detail about this study, but instead of typing out a dissertation in the comments I’ll just limit myself to discussing with people if anyone wants to talk about it. I’ll just be an internet crank and nitpick two tiny issues I had because you can’t get a PhD without becoming a pedant, apparently. 😊

HVC doesn’t stand for anything. It used to stand for High Vocal Center, and before that it was Hyperstriatum Ventrale pars Caudalis, but for fairly esoteric reasons the larger songbird research community decided that these were bad names. But, since we had been abbreviating the region as “HVC” for decades, no one wanted to change it so we just kept using the initialism “HVC” when referring to the region.

Next, calling NIf “the en-eye-eff” sounds weird to me. It stands for Nucleus Interfacialis (of the Nidopallium) and was usually pronounced “nif” in the research groups I was involved with.
/Rant

Memory implantation? Humbug. Once you can understand memory well enough to actually risk modification to a human brain (not in twenty to forty year --- sorry!) there would be little point in permanently implanting skill memories -- just network the consciousness into digital skill libraries so that needed skills can be swapped in on demand. Less mental clutter, better performance. This would probably require post scarcity economics, however, as there would no longer be a daily need for specialists once the skill libraries were compiled and published, so people could no longer earn a better living by becoming a specialist in a high demand field.
